awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: RoL:  Revealing a new mechanism of action for eukaryotic transcriptional activation domains
awd_abstract_narration:
This Rules of Life project seeks to discover new molecular mechanisms for turning genes on in eukaryotic cells.  Decades of previous research have led to the conventional belief that the proteins responsible for turning on, or activating, genes are locked into rigid shapes.  These shapes allow the proteins to interact with DNA, or with other proteins, like a key fits into a lock.  By contrast, this project will explore a new idea that the shape of activating proteins is not a rigid structure and that this lack of rigidity gives the proteins the ability to operate in extremely crowded cellular space and to interact in flexible ways with gene DNA.  This idea will be tested using a combination of laboratory experiments and computational approaches.  The results will improve fundamental understanding of how molecules interact with each other in the cell, thereby providing a conceptual foundation for applications such as advanced gene editing, personalized medicine or drug development.  The project will also have educational impact by providing multidisciplinary graduate and undergraduate STEM training at Butler University and Purdue University and by building a network of bioinformatics research communities in Indiana and other neighboring states through participation and organization of seminar series and workshops.

Transcriptional activation domains in transcription factors are widely believed to work via direct recruitment of coactivators and transcription initiation complex components.  Transcriptional activation domains are known to be very heterogeneous in their amino acid sequences, they have intrinsically disordered structure, and they have low affinity and specificity.  However, details of their mechanism of action remain elusive.  This project will test the novel idea that when coupled in the same transcription factor with a high-affinity DNA binding domain, transcriptional activation domains function to trigger chromatin remodeling through low-affinity interactions with nucleosomes, which then enable subsequent recruitment of nucleosome remodelers and transcriptional co-activators.  Experiments are designed to discriminate between the so-called "nucleosome detergent" model and the traditional direct recruitment model.  Gene activation mechanisms will be studied by the creation and screening of large complexity libraries of cells identical in all parameters other than the short (10-20 amino acids) transcription activation domain of the key gene activator, that is necessary for cell survival.  Individual libraries will be screened in vivo, sequenced at the DNA level using next generation sequencing techniques, and analyzed utilizing bioinformatics and machine learning.  Modifications related to the change of the intramolecular context of the key library-carrying gene activator, or the change of the reporter gene context, will help to extract key features of the transcriptional activation domains and the biological rules of eukaryotic gene activation. 

This award was jointly funded by the Genetic Mechanisms Program in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences, by the Infrastructure Innovations for Biological Research Program in the Division of Biological Infrastructure, and by the Rules of Life initiative of the Division of Emerging Frontiers in the Biological Sciences Directorate.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit

Activation and proper tuning of eukaryotic gene expression critically depend on the function of gene activators and are tightly related to numerous diseases and medical conditions. How activators work remains enigmatic for decades because the critical part of these molecules - activation domain (AD) sequences - do not follow the standard biochemical paradigm of specificity. In contrast to usual parts of proteins, ADs are short yet astronomically variable sequences of amino acids, are structurally disordered, and interact with an uncertain number of targets. In addition to the conventional view that ADs work by recruitment of necessary enzymes to regulatory parts of genes, we have formulated a hypothesis and obtained supporting experimental data that ADs are working as surfactants "cleaning" gene promoters from repressing nucleosomes and thus affecting the physical accessibility of gene promoters for components of transcriptional machinery.

On the conceptual level, we have realized and analyzed the reasons for the AD enigma to be so hard and long-standing and provided the ways out of the theoretical impasse (two review/perspectives papers are published, see Fig.1 with highlights).  Experimentally, we have developed a new high throughput assay for screening simultaneously 10^5 -10^6 created by us sequences for functionality as ADs in living cells.  Analyzing large AD libraries and using machine learning we found that while ADs do not have a consensus sequence and even short linear sequence motifs, they nevertheless follow two major rules: (i) the absence of basic and (ii) the simultaneous presence of acidic and aromatic amino residues. We then found that the AD functionality benefits from (iii) the redundancy of hydrophobic and acidic residues, while (vi) also being in balance with each other, and (v) from hydrophobic residues positioned toward the spatially freer end of the molecule, as well as (vi) not forming homo amino acid clusters. (vii) We were surprised to find that in the context of amphipathic (acidic residues on one side and hydrophobic residues on the other side) α-helix, often claimed as beneficial for AD functionality, the introduction of prolines (known as "helix breakers"), drastically increases the AD functionality. Importantly, hundreds of functional ADs can be composed of 10 amino acid sequences containing only tryptophan and aspartic acid, or phenylalanine and aspartic acid, or leucine and aspartic acid, with each synthetic AD sequence following the above rules. All findings above are consistent with the novel surfactant model of AD functionality (Fig. 2).

 

Broader impacts

While being scientifically paradigm-shifting as based on near-stochastic interactions, the surfactant model has implications for medicine and pharmacology if the AD AI models developed by us and others are applied to disease-related gene editing using CRISPR-Cas9 gene therapy approaches.

The collaborative project directly involved three Butler University (C. Class, M. Oliveira, A. Erkine) and one Purdue University (D. Kihara) faculty, a research scientist (G. Terashi, Purdue University), a postdoctoral fellows (D. Cooper, Butler University) and a research associates (T. Erkina, Butler University), four graduate students (F. Fareen, Y. Zhang, N. Ibtehaz, X. Wang) from Purdue, and more than ten undergraduates from Butler University who include women and underrepresented minority. All students involved acquired knowledge and skills both in biology/biochemistry and in computational sciences, mostly data analytics. The majority of students including undergraduates became coauthors on generated publications. 

At Butler University the project was presented in the "Brown Bag" series. The project stimulated further development of university-wide Data Analytics, and COPHS Pharmacy and BSHS programs, and inspired the creation of a new Bachelor of Pharmacy program emphasizing data analytics. The project contributed to the development of the University research infrastructure by stimulating new CPU and GPU purchases. At Purdue University, this research was integrated into bioinformatics courses. At the departmental level, the project stimulated hiring of two new Bioinformatics faculty (C. Class and A. Gulsevin) who are reshaping several courses in the above programs while also being involved in the collaborative research. At the international level, the collaborations were developed with the MRC LMB Cambridge University group in UK (M. Babu, C. Ravarani), the University of Copenhagen (B. Kragelund), and the University of Iceland (P. Heidarsson). Results, datasets, and concepts were presented and disseminated at multiple international conferences including Gordon research conferences on intrinsically disordered proteins, transcription regulation and chromatin, EMBO conference on chromatin and transcription, ASBMB conference on gene regulation, and multiple Bioinformatics conferences.
